slides.title: Introduction to Selenium
slides.content:
# Selenium üõ°Ô∏è

The industry veteran and most widely used tool for automative web testing across different browsers and platforms.

- **Multi-language**: Supports Java, Python, C#, Ruby, JS, and more.
- **Cross-browser**: Runs on Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge, and IE.
- **Open Source**: Huge community and ecosystem.

1. **Selenium IDE**: Browser extension for record-and-playback.
2. **Selenium WebDriver**: The core API used to write scripts.
3. **Selenium Grid**: Runs tests in parallel across multiple machines/OS.

slides.title: Locators
slides.content:
# Finding Elements üîç

- `By.id("id")` (Fastest)
- `By.name("name")`
- `By.cssSelector(".class")`
- `By.xpath("//button")` (Most Flexible but Slower)
- `By.linkText("Click Here")`

slides.title: Waiting in Selenium
slides.content:
# Timing is Everything ‚è≥

- **Implicit Wait**: Global timeout for finding elements.
- **Explicit Wait (WebDriverWait)**: Wait for a specific condition (e.g., `elementToBeClickable`).

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Use Explicit Waits! They make tests much more stable by checking conditions dynamically.

slides.title: Page Object Model (POM)
slides.content:
# Clean Design üèóÔ∏è

Separate your test logic from the page structure.

- **Page Class**: Defines elements and actions of a page.
- **Test Class**: Calls the Page Class to perform scenarios.

slides.title: Best Practices
slides.content:
# Pro Tips ‚úÖ

- **Don't use Threads.sleep()**.
- Keep your locators short and unique.
- Use **Data Provider** for parameterization.
- Close the driver in `@AfterMethod` to avoid memory leaks.
